Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Logic, Rewriting, and Concurrency

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the Workshop on Logic, Rewriting, and Concurrency is to provide an interdisciplinary research forum, focused on advancing the foundations of formal methods and reasoning about properties of cyber-physical systems and their safe, secure, and reliable operation in the real world. Such systems are rapidly becoming key component of critical infrastructure, medical systems, and artifacts that affect our daily lives such as smart buildings, wearables, and entertainment systems.

This workshop grant will enable students and speakers from many disciplines, from industry and academia, to participate in research discussions at this workshop with leading researchers about new approaches and applications of rewrite-rule systems for composability, symbolic analysis, temporal modeling, and verification of hybrid systems. The workshop will provide an opportunity for students and young researchers to interact with leaders in these important fields. The diverse experience and expertise of the participants coupled with a shared interest in rewriting and formal systems provides an ideal setting to foster new synergies and collaborations to address challenging problems in theory and applications to real world problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A symposium on Logic, Rewriting, and Concurrency  was held at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign on September 23-25, 2015. The goal of the symposium was to provide an interdisciplinary research forum, focused on advancing the foundations of formal methods and reasoning about properties of cyber-physical systems and their safe, secure, and reliable operation in the real world. Such systems are rapidly becoming key components of critical infrastructure, medical systems, and artifacts that affect our daily lives such as smart buildings, wearables, and entertainment systems. 

Twenty eight papers were presented, selected from thirty five submissions after a careful reviewing process; the symposium also featured two keynote talks. The topics included: Logic (including formal systems and theory of institutions), Formal Specification and Verification, Concurrency, Security, and Rewriting Logic (foundations,tolos, and applications).   The proceedings of the symposium have been published by Springer as volume 9200 of the Lecture Notes in Computer Science series.

The symposium brought together students and researchers from many disciplines, from industry and academia, to participate in discussions about new logical foundations and applications of rewrite-rule systems for composability, symbolic analysis, temporal modeling, and verification of hybrid systems. Thus the symposium provided an opportunity for students and young researchers to interact with leaders in the important fields of Logic, Rewriting, and Concurrency. The diverse experience and expertise of the participants coupled with a shared interest in rewriting and formal systems provided a venue for students to participate in discussions of challenging problems in theory and applications to real world problems. Students were encouraged to attend presentations and join networking sessions during breaks.
